history.proof: intros H. apply HR1. intros Q st2 H0 H1. shelve.

exceptions.exn: Applied theorem does not have enough premises.

chat.content:
I will give you a Coq proof state, including both hypotheses and a specific goal and your need to prove it. Your response should be a singular code block of Coq proof, without any additional explanation or commentary. Follow to these guidelines:
Introduce variables using unique names to avoid any conflicts.
Keep each command distinct and separated, avoid concatenations like ';' or '[cmd|cmd]'.
Organize your proof with bullets like '-', '+', and '*' instead of braces ({, }). Shift to their double symbols like '--' and '++', when necessary.
Effectively use given premises, follow the syntax and structure demonstrated in the examples provided.

Example 1:

Hypotheses:
n, m: nat
IHn: m + n = n + m

Goal:
m + S n = S n + m

Proof:
```simpl. rewrite <- IHn. auto.```

Example 2:
Hypotheses:

Goal:
forall n m : nat, m + n = n + m

```intros n m. induction n.
- simpl. auto.
- simpl. rewrite <- IHn. auto.```

Sovle This Proof State:

Hypotheses:
instr: Set
data: Type
one_step: instr -> state -> state -> Prop
sss_fun: forall (i : instr) (s t1 t2 : state), s ⟬ i ⦒ t1 -> s ⟬ i ⦒ t2 -> t1 = t2
sss_dec: forall (i : instr) (st1 st2 : state), {st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2} + {~ st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2}
P: code
R: state -> Prop
HR0: forall st : state, out_code (fst st) P -> R st
HR1: forall st1 : state, (forall (Q : subcode.code instr) (st2 : state), Q <sc P -> Q // st1 -+> st2 -> P // st2 ↓ -> R st2) -> R st1
st: state

Goal:
P // st ↓ -> R st

subcode_sss_terminates_instr : forall (P : code) (i : instr) (st1 st2 : state), st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2 -> (fst st1, i :: nil) <sc P -> P // st2 ↓ -> P // st1 ↓
subcode_sss_step_inv_1 : forall (P : code) (i : instr) (st1 st2 : state), (fst st1, i :: nil) <sc P -> P // st1 :1> st2 -> st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2
subcode_sss_compute_instr : forall (P : code) (i : instr) (st1 st2 st3 : state), st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2 -> (fst st1, i :: nil) <sc P -> P // st2 -> > st3 -> P // st1 -> > st3
in_sss_step : forall (k : nat) (l : list instr) (i : instr) (r : list instr) (st1 st2 : state), fst st1 = k + length l -> st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2 -> (k, l ++ i :: r) // st1 :1> st2
sss_step = fun (P : code) (st1 st2 : state) => exists (k : nat) (l : list instr) (i : instr) (r : list instr) (d : data), P = (k, l ++ i :: r) /\ st1 = (k + length l, d) /\ st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2 : code -> state -> state -> Prop
subcode_sss_terminates_inv : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st st1 : state), Q // st ↓ -> P <sc Q -> P // st ~~> st1 -> Q // st1 ↓
subcode_sss_compute_inv : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st3 : state), P <sc Q -> out_code (fst st3) P -> Q // st1 -> > st3 -> exists st2 : state, P // st1 -> > st2 /\ Q // st2 -> > st3 /\ out_code (fst st2) P
sss_stall = fun (ii : instr) (st : state) => forall st' : state, ~ st ⟬ ii ⦒ st' : instr -> state -> Prop
sss_steps_ind : forall (P : code) (P0 : nat -> state -> state -> Prop), (forall st : state, P0 0 st st) -> (forall (n : nat) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 :1> st2 -> P//st2-[n]->st3 -> P0 n st2 st3 -> P0 (S n) st1 st3) -> forall (n : nat) (p p0 : state), P//p-[n] -> p0 -> P0 n p p0
subcode_sss_progress : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st2 : state), P <sc Q -> P // st1 -+> st2 -> Q // st1 -+> st2
subcode_sss_step_inv : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st2 : state), P <sc Q -> in_code (fst st1) P -> Q // st1 :1> st2 -> P // st1 :1> st2
sss_step_subcode_inv : forall (P : code) (ii : instr) (st st' : state), (fst st, ii :: nil) <sc P -> P // st :1> st' -> st ⟬ ii ⦒ st'
sss_step_fun : forall (P : code) (s t1 t2 : state), P // s :1> t1 -> P // s :1> t2 -> t1 = t2
subcode_sss_compute_trans : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P <sc Q -> P // st1 -> > st2 -> Q // st2 -> > st3 -> Q // st1 -> > st3
subcode_sss_step : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st2 : state), P <sc Q -> P // st1 :1> st2 -> Q // st1 :1> st2
subcode_sss_compute : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st1 st2 : state), P <sc Q -> P // st1 -> > st2 -> Q // st1 -> > st2
subcode_sss_progress_inv : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (p : nat) (st1 st2 st3 : state), out_code (fst st3) P -> P <sc Q -> P // st1 -+> st2 -> Q//st1-[p] -> st3 -> exists q : nat, q < p /\ Q//st2-[q] -> st3
Inductive sss_steps (P : code) : nat -> state -> state -> Prop := in_sss_steps_0 : forall st : state, P//st-[0] -> st | in_sss_steps_S : forall (n : nat) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 :1> st2 -> P//st2-[n] -> st3 -> P//st1-[S n] -> st3 Arguments sss_steps _ _%nat_scope Arguments in_sss_steps_S [P] [n]%nat_scope [st1 st2 st3]
subcode_sss_compute_linstr : forall (k : nat) (li : list instr) (P : code) (st1 st2 st : state), (fst st1, li)//st1-[k] -> st2 -> (fst st1, li) <sc P -> P // st2 -> > st -> P // st1 -> > st
sss_step_supcode : forall (P : subcode.code instr) (Q : code) (st st' : state), P <sc Q -> in_code (fst st) P -> Q // st :1> st' -> P // st :1> st'
sss_progress_trans : forall (P : code) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 -+> st2 -> P // st2 -+> st3 -> P // st1 -+> st3
sss_progress_compute_trans : forall (P : code) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 -+> st2 -> P // st2 -> > st3 -> P // st1 -+> st3
sss_compute_progress_trans : forall (P : code) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 -> > st2 -> P // st2 -+> st3 -> P // st1 -+> st3

```  
intros H.
apply HR1.
intros Q st2 H0 H1.
apply H.
Qed.
